; St Big Quota of First Call
eaves for Camp Meade
Sunday
WILL GO

to the training grounds and trenches,
To rally ‘neath the flag of freedom;
to meet the Kaiser's Boches
down the Prussian vandalism.

Of tomorrow morning for Camp Meade,
last large contingent of selected men to
er the first call from this city leaves
thé Baltimore and Ohio Terminal and the
forth Philadelphia Station of the Penn-
@ylvania Railroad on special trains with
farewells, the kisses and tears inter-
Milngled of family and friends bidding god-
“‘Bpeed branded on their memories forever.
Close to 3500 selected men from the
fifty-one local draft districts in this city
@re to eritrain, the schedule times of de-
Parture stretching from 9 in the moring to
2 in the afternoon. The various details
@re being called together for the prelimi-
“mary rolicail and final instructions
Some persons are waxing wealthy on the |
Dusiness of hunting these foreigners and |
Americans, and one man bill for
$1500, at $50 per head, awaiting settlement
By the Government. Mr. Swift maintains
that the usual floating population of that
Section should have into
@ideration when the quota was made up, as |

he now has a list of 250 missing men, |
which is almost as many as the quota culls
for.

Local draft district No. 1, embracing the
First Ward, sends ninety-two men, with a
kit containing cigars, cigarettes and a spe-
@lal souvenir presented to each by Frank
Lapidus and Samuel Greenburg, members
of the board, who will accompany the men
to the cantonment. They will parade to
the station escorted by two bands.

The Third District, taking in Ward Three,
@ends forty men, headed by Gustave Mur- |
Phy. The Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Dis-
tricts, including the east and west por-
tions, are represented by 100 and 150, com-
Manded by Albert Heymann and Samuel
Buck, respectively, and escorted by the
Police band of the Seventeenth District, and
the Twenty-second draft district, with had-
quarters at Fifteenth street and Snyder ave-
nue, is surrendering 112 draftees, led by W.
E. Barcus.
NONE FROM TWENTY-SIXTH BOARD

The Second District sends eighty candl-
Gates, guided by Henry “%. Rohlfing, from
the station house at Seventh and Carpenter
Streets. The Twenty-sixth District board
fs not reporting any men, as it says it did
Mot receive its list of certified men in time
to call them cut

A Boy Scout band is to accompany the
forty-eight and fifty draftees from the
Twenty-fourth and Twenty-fifth Districts,
Fespectively, embracing the east and west
Portions of Ward 28, although there will
be two other bands in line and many citi-
Sens.

The Manayunk Business Men's Associa-
tion is presenting each of the boys from
the Fourteenth District with a safety razor,
trench mirror and a box of lunch. On the
aarade to the station they will be escorted

y a band, members of the draft board, the
home defense reserve and a squad of police
Under Lieutenant Taylor.

The men from District No. 43, Branch-
town, which includes Olney, Logan, Fern
Rock, Oak Lane and Branchtown, leave for
Logan Station, accompanied by two bands,
Members of the Logan Improvement Asso-
Ciation and home defense reserves, Boy
Scouts and a squad of police under Lieu-
tenant Hamilton, of the Thirty-fifth Police
District One hundred and eleven men will
leave this section to fight the Huns.

Automobiles will take the ninety-seven
Fecruits from the Mhirty-third District
headquarters, 6047 Market street, to the
Baltimore and Ohio station, Twenty-fourth
and Chestnut streets. A band concert will
be given in«their honor tonight at their
headquarters and J. BE. Travis, chairman
of the Exemption Board, will make an
address. Members of the Sixtieth and
Market Streets Business Men's Association
will accompany them to the.train.

The eighty-five men from the Forty-first |
District will leave the S. Weir Mitchell
Public School at 8 o'clock tomorrow morn-
ing and stop for a chicken breakfast at
Thirty-second and Chestnut Streets before
entraining at the Baltimore and Ohio sta-
tion. The Rev. Lord Gimberson and Sam-
wel Crothers, members of the Forty-second
District Board, will address the fifty
@raftees from that section at the rolleall
topight. The 108 recruits from the Forty.
sixth District will meet this afternoon in
the Franklin Theatre and be addressed by
Joseph S. MacLaughlin, Director of the
Department of Supplies, and J J. Bradley,
chairman of the board.

The Lancaster Avenue Business Men's As-
®ociation is giving a dinner tonight to its
Getail of twenty-five men. Two British
Soldiers, now in this city to aid British
Fecruiting, will tell the men what to expect
in Europe. The men will be presented with
trench mirrors and tobacco. They also
will have a band on their march from
headquarters of the Twentieth District to
Thirty-ninth and easter avenue to the
Station. Fifteen men from the Nineteenth |
District will accompany them.

The parties from Tacony, Bridesburg, |
Frankford, Chestnut Hill and Germantown |
take trains from their local stations for |
North Philadelphia, where they join the
@ther draftees for Camp Meade They '!n-
elude sixty-nine men from the Thirty-fourth
District, 103 from the Forty-seventh Diu-
trict, ninety-four from the Eighteenth Dis-
trict, forty from the Fifteenth District
Seventy-four from the Sixteenth District
@nd fifty from the Seventeenth District,
Tespectively, ai two being from Ger-
Mantown
y The fifteen men from the. Sixth District
will be led by Edward Silverstein. They
will march from their headquarters, at
Twelfth and Pine streets, to the Baltimore
and Ohio’ terminal.
Fifteen footballs are included in the lug-

of the ninety men from District No. 4,
mg preserited. by the Fourth Ward Re-
lican Club, When they leave their head-

rs, at Third- and De Lancey streets,
morrow morning to entrain at Broad
t Station of the Pennsylvania Rall-

‘oad they will be headed by Albert Leidlein
ana Samuel Levin.

MEN OF WAR EXPERIENCE

Allentown District Campaigners
for Big Fund Hear Presi-
dent’s Son-in-Law
HE PRESIDES AT DINNER

Dedication of Association Hut at Am-
bulance Camp Follows Forming
of Money Plans

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 3
Bowes Sayre, son-in-law of
President Wilson, came here today at noon
to aid in dedicating the new army Y. M.
C. A. hut at the United States Ambulance
Camp. He proceeded immediately to the
o @& G Ay he presided at
dinner given at 1 o'clock by the Twelfth
(Allentown) District of the Pennsylvania
War Council. This district is composed of
Lehigh, Northampton and Carbon countie
and its allotment is $165,000 of the $35,000,-
000 to be raised during the week begin-
ning November 11 in the great campaign for
the maintenance and expansion of the In-
ternational Y. M. C. A,

Superior Court Judge Frank M. Trex-
ler is district chairman and Captain H. Wg
EFlvidge, secretary of the Allentown Y, M.
C. A. 18 campaign executive in charge of
work ag thic “War
Council, The dinner and meeting were at
tended by more than 100 the .most

prominent aid active citizens the three
counties,
Francis
city where a
representative ol
of
of

| caramels
| American pie to be sold at cost prices

n France
and Italy and told them pressing

necessity of raising the
7: oC A, purposes, of which approximate-

listed men of the

The $1,000,000 for prison camps will be
expended mostly in Germany and Austria,
which, together, Mr. Sayre said, have 8&5
per cent of the prisoners captured in this
war and the condition of most
extremely deplorable,

The men at the Council decided t |
work with a will and raise the
of this district. Allentown is supposed

ton $35,000 and Mauch Chunk $30,000,
of them is

Arch Johnston, vice president of the
Bethlehem Steel Company, who will be the
new Maycr of Bethlehem, was present and,
with all that his personality implies, will
aid the work in Northampton County, which
will be in charge of Secretary Bracefield,
while in Carbon County the head of the or-
ganization will be Secretary Boettcher. Al-
lentown and Lehigh will be organized and
campaigned under the personal direction of
Captain Elvide

Mr. Sayre expressed himself as delighted
with the spirit of enthusiasm and patriotism
displayed by the men at the conference and
thanked them in behalf of the international
organization and in the name of humanity.

A letter from Judge Buffington to Mayor
A, L. Reichenbach, of Allentown, was read
It strongly indorsed the campaign to raise
the war fund.

After the war work conference, Mr, Sayre,
escorted by all the notables present and the
officers of the ambulance service, proceeded
to the ambulance camp, where he delivered
the principal address at the dedication of
the new army Y. M. C. A. building. Here he |
also outlined the work in France and Italy.
The Rey. Dr. W. E. Brooks performed the
rites of dedication, assisted by Monsignor |
Masson, Bishop Talbot and Rabbi Tarshish,

Funeral services were held today for
Patrol” Sergeant John Crossin, of the
Twenty-sixth and York streets police sta-
tien, at I y. m., at his late home, 2538
North Thirty-first street. One patrol ser-
geant from each police district in the city
all act, Crossia, who died on Tuesday

SERVES SAMMEES
Establishes First of Chain
and Service Centers

| DAINTIES AT COST RATES
oe
By HENRI BAZIN

Staff Correspondent of the Evening Ledger with
the American Army in France

| AMERICAN FIELD HEADQUARTERS
i tN FRANCE, Sept, 30.

' he American Salvation Army {8 “on
the job” somewhere in France. In a little
while it will be “somewhere,” and that in
Under the supreme direction
of Colonel William 8. Barker, of New York,
ind the direct personal direction of Staff
Captain Willlam Halpin, who comes from
Mhiledelphia, the first Salvation Army hut
thrown many miles
where these lines are written.
quantities
vas today not

open
from
The hut is really a long sectional wooden
puilding, 150 by 40 feet, brilliantly lighted
through ten windows upon each side. The
door at one end is as wide as the wel-
me that goes with it. I did not measure
{, but Sammees in columns of fours could
pass through with room to spare,
The hut is in charge of Ensign Hickey,

10 has five men and six Salvation lassies
They are all musicians and will
give concerts and song services for the
Sammees at frequent intervals. They pro-
pose, in addition, making fudge, home-made
and cikes, with real
vith him
cookies

The aim of this Salvation Army venture
in a measure different from the aims
generally associated with the army's work
at home. Religion is by no means the main
scheme in view, but rather righteousness,
and the salvation of the body, coupled with
clean, healthy, moral pastiming. To that
end the huts will be used for service and
Bible classes on Wednesday and Sunday
evenings. At all other times they will be at
the disposal of the Sammees for denomina-
tional services, or club and fraternity meet-
ings. Already arrangements have been
made for a Jewish service by the Hebrew
Sammees of the battalion quartered near
the hut, and the Loyal Order of the Moose
will have an initiation and lodge meeting
during the coming week.

The six women rank as captains tn the
Salvation Army. Thelr names are Edith
Hickey, wife of the ensign in charge;
Helen Purviance, Margaret Sheldon, Geneva
Ladd, Elsie Merrifield and Frances Reuton
They come from Chicago and western
points. It is their intention to open a
clothes-mending bureau, and to darn socks,
sew on buttons and repair rents in khaki
trousers free of charge. All Sammee has
to do is to bring his torn or worn duds, and
get 'em back ready to wear in a few days

The influence of these six women has
already been felt in the village where the
hut has been erected. They are the first
American women who have come into the
army zene to live the life of the troops and
as such, are looked upon in respectful won-
der. They will cook their own meals in
quarters attached to one end of the hut,
and sleep on Sammee cots, rising at revelille,
and being ready to serve at al] hours. The
Salvation Army men will live In tents and
take mess with the Sammees,

Stiff Captain Halpin, who is in charge
of the enterprise directly on the job In the
zone, told your correspondent that the Sal-
vation Army expects to put up a similar
hut in every town and village in the zone.

Captain Halpin. who is a member of the
Philadelphia Musical Union and is well
known at Salvation Army headquarters,
Eighth and Vine streets, {s establishing a
newspaper section of the hut. His alm is
to supply newspapers from every town in
the United States from whence hail the
Sammees, in sections where the original
hut stands, and where all future ones are
to be erected. I found that as usual among
all young Sammees that I have talked with
in these somewhere in France, that a fair
proportion hat!l from Philadelphia, and I
started the newspaper section by handing
to Captain Halpin seven coples of the
EVENING LEDGER, with the promise to let
him have more as time went on. When 1
left for correspondents’ headquarters, seven
different Sammees were looking at these
seven different EVENING LEDGERs, and
every mother's son of them had his paper
open at the sports page, giving the baseball]
news the earnest once over.

ROLAND B. MOLINEUX
DIES IN L. I. HOSPITAL

Chemist and Playwright Once in Sing |
Sing Death Cell for
Murder

NEW YORK, Nov. 3.—Roland B.. Moll-
neux, central figure in the famous murder
known as the ‘Molineux
nearly twenty years ago, died yesterday in
a Long Island Hospital
mystery case,”

Molineux was arrested after Mrs, Kate
Adams had died from drinking poison con-
tained in a headache potion. It was al-
leged the polson was sent by Molineux to
1 fellow club member who boarded:at Mrs
Adams's home and who was a rival of
Molineux in the courtship of Blanche Chese-
borough. Before Molineux wis brought to
trial in November, 1899, he married Miss
Cheseborough. Subsequently his wife qi-
vorced him

Molineux suffered a
from overwork in writing “The Man In-
side," which was produced in 1913 as a
play He was sent four years ago to the
asylum in which he died. His second wife,
who was Miss Margaret Connell, and their
child were at his side. He was about fifty-
two years old. N

In the world of commerce Roland Burn-
ham Molineux was the name of a chemist.
In the literary and dramatic circles the
name stands for a playwright and writer
of no small ability. In the public mind the
name is indelibly associated with two fa-
mous murder trials in which Molineux stood
accused of causing the death of Mrs. Adams,

The prosecution charged that Molineux
sent the headache powders containing the
poison to Harry Cornish. The prominence
of the accused man and of his father, Gen-
eral Edward Leslie Molineux, an English-
man who had fought for the United States
in the Civil War, and had afterward made
a fortune in the paint manufacturing busi-
ness in Brooklyn, added to the public
interest.

Molineux, convicted at the first trial, after
weary months in the Tombs, was sent to the
death house at Sing Sing, where he spent
nearly two yeirs In the company of doomed
men before he was granted a new trial and
acquitted.

YOUR LETTERS ARE INTERESTING
TO MAN IN NEXT STREET-CAR SEAT

World Is Fond of Looking Over Somebody’s
Shoulder—Prying Questions to Strangers
Easier on Eyes and on the Honor
E WERE reading my letter—he and I.

This, dear friends, may sound like
an ode to a tender memory; but wait—
it happened on a street car!

From the first the stranger in the
next seat had been interested in my letter.
At one time his interest mounted to such
fever heat that I felt it would be cruel
and unfeeling to turn to page two with-
out asking if he, too, were ready,
Has this ever happened to you?

When read a letter on the street
car does not the world try to peer over
your shoulder and wriggle around to see
what's in it?) 1 once knew a young man
who was writing—not reading—a letter
on the train, when he discovered the eyes
of a refined looking man having a per-
fectly beautiful time with his affairs, In-
stead of pulling the letter back into se-
clusion he pushed it into plainer view.
Then he wrote: “I hope you won't have
as hard a time reading this letter as the
man jin the next
you
seat is!’
| dle all very well to be sweet and un-

selfish and to maintain a kindly inter-
in your neighbor aftairs. But there's
a time for this. And that time isn't on
the street car or train when you've never
even had the pleasuro of your neighbor's
acquaintance.
est

It's bad enough to read your neigh-
bor’s newspaper, but this, in spite of the
etiquette experts, is sometimes excusable;
at least until you've read the headlines,
any way. But a letier! It would be far
better to take out a little notebook and
ask the woman in the next seat if she'd
mind just giving a few little pointers
about herself—who her friends were, if
she went away in the summer and some
little things like that. This would be

PATSY KILDARE
THE OUTLAW
By JUDD MORTIMER LEWIS

The Capture
eo and I sat a long time last night
on the step of the house where the man
j lives who is a hundred years old, There

“were not many stars to look at, so we
| looked at what stars there were. I eweew
Cod was too busy to hang out all the stars,
but we should ‘have been as well satisfied if
He had hung out only one, You can look
at but one star at a time, anyway. I was
telling Rowdy about the stars and about
all the angels in heaven that I know—the
angels that have been there a long time and
are now good at flying and those that
have just gone lately and have to fly with
one foot on a cloud till they get used to
wings-—when the first thing I knew there
I was with my head on Rowdy for a pillow
|}and the sky was getting pale and I was
ting yet,

Many a one would be tickled with
a spray of paradise feathers placed
on a hat like this.
hard the and infinitely
easier on the honor.
less on eyes
cold as a pickle

1 went into the house and made a fire in
the kichen to warmup by and when I was

arm I went and milked the cow and the
nan who is a hundred years old was sleep-
so I ate bread and milk and gave
ltowdy a pan of milk, which he ate, though
| guess he wished milk had a bone in it
Then I took the hoe and made a hole for
the dead dog and rolled it in a blanket
and buried it. As Rowdy and I were going
away through the hole in the vines an auto
came along and a lady who was in it said,
“Little girl, do you live here?" I said, “Yes,
ma’am, sometimes.” She said, ‘Could you
fet me a glass of milk?” So I did and she
drank it and gave me a quarter.

The man who is a hundred years old had
rot up when I went into the house, so I
| gave the money to him. He went into his
bedroom and shut the door and I saw him

ETTERS are queer things. We watch
L some of our friends get letters with
a sense of dread. We know we are going
to have to listen to them later.

That's the general attitude about listen-
ing to mail that comes to casual acquaint
ances, We sinip'y aren't intereste’l,
We're bored and wish they'd keep the
men they met this summer to themselves.

This being the world’s attitude toward
the intimate affairs of casual friends,
wouldn't {t be relieving if the rule held
good with people the world never met
at all?

Everybody could read letters on the
trolley car and, raising a head suddenly,
could find their neighbor's eye honestly
and calmly fastened on an overhead ad-
vertisement!
must be written on

one side of
Special queries
writer, like those given
THE
TODAY'S INQUIRIES
1. How should men’s ‘half silk’’ shirts be
laundered?

2. Which are the most wholesome fats to use
{mn the cooking of fried stuffs?

8. What will keep the windows from freezing
and becoming hard to open in cold weather?

1. How can ‘‘furs’’ for a very little girl be

ANSWERS TO YESTERDAY’S INQUIRIES

1, Indelible pencil mark stains can be removed
with grain or wood alcohol, Soak the stains
for a few minutes until they are dissolved. The
graphite marks still stay, but these can be
washed out with soap and water,

2. Badly bruised potatoes can be made into
potato starch, This is done by a simple process
in which the potatoes are cus up, skins and
all, put through a grinder and allowed to soak
in saturations of cold water until starch forms
in the bottom of the pall and the peelings and
seum rise to the surface, The starch ts used
in making custards, ete,

8. When there is no shower bath or shower
hose convenient a sprinkling can serves admir-
ably for rinsing the children's hair.
Home for Newlywed
To the Editor of Woman’s Page:

Dear Madam—wWill you please publish in
your column whether it would be appropriate
to have a kitchen cabinet and an ordinary closet
in a large kitchen which has tile walls and
metal ceiling? Is it proper to have frames on
the walls of a kitchen? What other _informa-
tion can you give regarding same? This is a
new home which is being built and is expected to
be completed in a few weeks. I would also like
you to suggest a pretty way to arrange my
dining room We have hardwood floors in the
dining room, Dutch hall and sitting room
Would it be better to have rugs or runners on
these floors? I understand that it is very hard
to keep the runners in place, and, again, I
don't Iike to have the pretty floors covered with
rugs. 1 would like you to give me littie sug-
gestions that wouid help to beautify the home.
What is the best cleanser for hardwood floors?
\ d of fiames should be. placed on walls

ing room and Dutch hall?
ieee ANXIOUS NEWLYWED.
The modern kitchen cabinet has a place
for everything that is ordinarily placed in |}

the kitchen cupboard. However, as the
kitchen is large and there is room for a
cupboard, it would come in very handy as a
storing place for extra dishes and large
kitchen utensils, ete. No pictures are used
on kitchen walls. Have a metal-toppea
kitchen table. Cover floor with lnoleum.
Piace the kitchen furniture in such position
as to save steps for the one who is to work
in it. For instance, put the kitchen cabinet
where it will be convenient to the stove and
the sink.

American walnut furniture is being used
in dining rooms and old blue window hang-
ings look yery well with it. If your wall
is plain have figured hangings, but if not,
have plain ones. Center your sideboard in
a wall space and balance it in another part
of the room with a buffet or serving table.
In the smaller dining rooms little console
tables are taking the place of long buffets
These do not take up very much space and
are very pretty. Over a console table hangs
a mirror, which should be hung to directly
face the opening of the dining room on to
the Dutch hail. On the console a pair of
candlesticks look very well.

Have one large rug in your dining room,
as dining room furniture is very apt to
scratch the floor. The fact that small rugs
or runners slip need not keep you from
having them in your sitting room and Dutch
hall, for there are little rubber treads that
come to keep them fast to the floor. If you
are planning to have very good small rugs,
while the floors are new they will probably
show them off to better advantage than the
large rugs. Sometimes, though, a large rug
seems to add more warmth and coziness
to a room,

One might write a volume on suggestions
to beautify the home. Here, however, are
twe rules: Be careful to use colors, not
that always match, but that always har-
monize. Do not load the house up with
pictures and bric-a-brac. There is beauty in
simplicity.

Hardwood floors can be wiped up with a
cloth wrung out in lukewarm weak white
suds, They can be polished with a piéce
of brussels carpet tacked around a brick.
The department stores sell very good polish-
ing oil, with which it is well to go over the
floors occasionally, At house-cleaning time
they should have a thorough going over.
Use frames that match or tone in with the
wood in the hall and sitting room. Dark
wood is preferred to gilt ones.

Seeks to Regain Lover
To the Editor of Woman's Page:

Dear Madam-—I am a young girl
years of age and am considered A$
'yY Persons of both sexes. Even the
it. I have been in love with
peniy for pore than a
blond move nto our neighborh
friend was introduced to fry crs ie net
been to see me since, I am heart-broken
shall I do to regain his love? ;
tell me will help me I know,

seventeen
beautiful
girls admit
@ young man of
year, Last month a

What
Anything vou can
BLUE EYES,

I am very sorry for you, Blue Eyes, but
I am afraid you have given your heart to
one who is not worthy of its affection. If,
after knowing you for a year and having
said that he loved you, he can suddenly
stop coming to see you at the mere meeting
of another woman who attracts him, I

would not see a happy life ahead r
with such a fickle companion, yd nd
cupy yourself with other things and forget
this young man, who is so evidently un-
worthy of your love, and in time the wound
will heal, for you are yet very young, and it
would be really unwise to decide on your
life partner now at any rate. Work for the
Red Cross or some home charity and you
will meet @ finer man some day who will be
worthy of sincere affection.

Tullps, hyacinths and daffodils can be
planted for the next two or three weeks out-
doors. Plant about three. times the size
of the bulb deep and cover around with
grace cuttings or leaves. When planted out-

oors they require no care until blooming
time. They can be planted indoors in peb-
bles or pots for a month yet. Keep in dark
Place until foliage is formed and bring into
the light for blooming, Tuberoses and
gladioluses are planted in late May or June.

Dahlias should be taken up goon. Keep
them in a moderately coo) and thoroughly
dry cellar in the dark. A little earth about
the roots will help. Plant again some time

put it through a crack in the floor, for I
peeped at him through the keyhole. He came
cut looking as if he ‘thought he had done
something smart, and he said, "I am a
hundred years old.” I did not laugh, be-
cause you shouldn't laugh at any one who
basn’t any sense and can’t help it.

When I got back to Mr. Rockrudder’s I
told the burglar all about the hoboes and
what Rowdy did to them. He got pale and
said, “I wish you were my girl.” IT said, “1
should think you would, for anybody would
be lucky to have a girl like me." He said,
“You certainly do dislike yourself.” I don't
know what made him think that, for f
don't.

I had not been in school very long today
when a policeman came for me. The police
had arrested the ‘hoboes on suspicion and the
burglar saw it in the paper and phoned the
rolice about what they did to the man who
is a hundred years old. So the policeman
took me to the station to see if I knew
them, and I picked them out of a crowd and
Rowdy nearly picked them out, too, bue
made him stop. They certainly were chewed
up. The police made me tell them who
may father is, for I have got to come again
when the hoboes are tried. Then al! the
policemen remembered me, because I had
helped to catch the gnomes under the bank
By the time they were through with me it
was too late for school, a policeman
phoned for Levy and I rnade him take me to
J:m's and Maggie's, They have got a baby
cow, which they have named Patsy Kildare,
and I am going to teach it to do tricks. If
I can teach it to turn over endways I think
I can start a show in our kitchen or some-
where and make a lot of money. I will
need it, for it is going to cost a lot to
take care of my burglar, for, of course, he
can’t burgle any more,

Maggie sat on the floor with me like a
regular child, and we cut out paper dolls
and then she and Jim and Rowdy and ;
played hide and seek around the house and
the barn and I nearly laughed my head
off. When I went to bed Rowdy and I
prayed, ‘Dear mother which art in heaven
and God, hollered be Thy name, If you
know anything about training a baby cow
I hope you will help me. You, God, please
bless my father and my mother. Amen.”

IN THE MOMENTS >
MODES

Cape Scarf and Muff of
Hudson Bay Sable
After all, the main charm of a caps

is the way it falls in ripples across
the back, and the main charm of
a stole is the way the long, flat
ends fall in front. So here are the
best features of the two styles com.
bined in one neckpiece. Two of the
richest and most beautiful of furs
have been used in this model. It is
of Hudson Bay sable, entirely
lined with ermine, the ermine
showing where it is turned back
at the neck and under the stole
ends. In the back of this scarf
is a real cape, very full, that
falls to the waist line. The muff is
rather large and shows the ermine
lining at the opening.
A New Lingerie Clasp
A new little lingerie clasp has crept inte
being. It's not of gold or silver. It's of rik
bon and the lovely thing about it is one may
have as many of them as there are shade
of camisoles. Just an inch wide.is this
little new comer, which does its work
fectively because firm snapper clasps finish
it off. Quarter-inch wide ribbon is used
and it takes about three inches to make
each clasp. This allows the hems to b

turned far enough back to make a firm
foundation for sewing on the clasps, The
ribbon must be of a good heavy variety in
order to keep in shape.

A set of these little clasps in different
colors boxed with little corsage sachet pads
to match would make charming little Christe |
mas gifts.
GOOD HEALTH QUESTION BOX
In answer to health questions,

FEW
taken

simple exercises,
without the help of teacher

will enable one to get the right position in
sitting.
a
EXERCISE 1

Place the hands upon the hips, with the
thumbs back and the forearms straight,
Bring the elbows up and carry the thumbs
back as far as possible. Look up at the
ceiling, carrying the head back until you
are looking straight up. Press with the
thumbs as hard as you can upon the back,
and draw down the chin. You will then
{have a good position, with the chest well
out, which is the object of this exercise,
EXERCISE 2,

Start from the same position as before,
with the hands upon the hips and the
thumbs well back, and the head turned
toward the ceiling. Keep looking up at
the ceiling while bending slowly forward
at the hips as far as possible. Slowly raise
the trunk, still looking at the ceiling, press-
ing hard with the thumbs, and drawing
the chin in, That brings the body up in
splendid position,
EXERCISE

Sit well forward on the front edge of
the chair, facing the wall, with the toes
against the wall so that the body may be
kept balanced. Place the hands upon the
hips and bend slowly backward until the
head touches the back of the chair. Press
the thumbs upon the back, draw the chin
in, and come slowly forward to proper
position, Count four while bending back-
ward, and four while coming forward,
EXERCISE 4

Sit well forward in the chair, with the
feet spread apart a little and flat on the
floor, Grasp the seat of the chair firmly,
look up at the ceiling, and push the chest
forward as far as possible while holding
on to the chair with the hands. That pulis
the chest up and the shoulders back. Try
to slide forward as far as possible while
holding yourself back. In this way the
chest is forced out, even in a person who
is really flat-chested.

The correct standing position is easily
acquired by a little practice, The improve-
ment in health and personal appearance is
so great as to make worth while the effort
to obtain a good poise and graceful posi-
tion, First of all, it is necessary to get
a correct idea of the erect position. With
the aid of a teacher this can be acquired
in a few minutes, Having no teacher, one
may employ a wall as a trainer,

of the spine in a person thirty-five youre re |
¥. Z,

If it ts a lateral curvature and i¢ by
muscular effort you can siraighten up, the
curvature may be corrected entirely. I¢ it
has become permanently rigid, it cannot be
entirely corrected,

Tea and Coffee
If I seem able to use tea and coffee with no
bad effects, may I not continue to use. them?
MRS. T. g,
If a person uses tea or coffee until he

sees the bad effects, very great harm has
already been done, These nareptics pro-
duce degeneracy—not simply disturbance,
Changes occur jn the arteries and the nerve
and in the tissues of the body generally,
until they become so injured that they are
unable to perform their functions properly,

JELLIED WALDORF SALAD
The ingredients are one-half of a packs
age of gelatin, one-half cupful of cold
water, one cupful of boiling water, one 7
quarter of a cupful of sugar, one-quarter”
of a cupful of lemon juice, two cupfuls of
chopped apple, one cupful of shredded —
celery, one-half cupful of nut meats chopped,”
lettuce and mayonnaise y
Soak gelatin in cold water five minutes.
Add boiling water, sugar and lemon juice. |
Chill until it begins to stiffen. Add apples, —
celery and nuts. Turn into individual 4
molds and chill, Serve on lettuce with
mayonnaise.—Better Meals for Less Money. ©
